Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit where it pleases - "waiting my turn" -, while the Dutch continue with their long-standing tradition of queueing (the 10-minute extended coffee breaks are just another reinforcement), accept whatever crummy spot they can find.

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well tended crow's nests notwithstanding. Unfortunately the pace is incredibly glacial and after attempting to watch 130 minutes of it earlier in the week I wound up falling asleep. Parts of Cara Brace's script make sense while others do not, some holes leave gaping plot gaps while others are buried by pointless sub-plots

The Bone Snatcher is about a group miners who go on a search for a missing crew of miners in the Namib Desert. When the find them, they do not realize that they are going up against an alien monster.
This film has some great scares and humorous moments. It's filmed with handheld camcorder style which takes some getting used to, but once you get past that fact, there is lots of action and interesting storylines.

Snow White is in my opinion a bad movie on an artistic point of view. The plot is pretty much foreseeable, the characters are stereotypes, the editing too. The movie was pale by comparison to My Life as a Zucchini.

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is clearly an attempt to catch the success of The A-Team and Commando, but it ultimately fails to deliver due to its embarrassingly low budget and overexaggerated jokes.
